image.altText: Lightning striking a boat.

props.synopsis: Severe storms across Australia's east coast have claimed the lives of six people as clean-up continues across several states.

title.children: Six dead, including 9yo girl as Christmas and Boxing Day storms lash Australia's east coast

image.altText: A man smiling.

props.synopsis: Bill Granger has died in hospital in London, his family has announced. The renowned chef and food writer ran 19 restaurants around the world.

title.children: 'The world has lost a special person': Food world 'heartbroken' at death of celebrity chef Bill Granger

image.altText: Australia batter Marnus Labuschagne watches a ball run away after a cricket shot.

props.synopsis: The Boxing Day Test is in an interesting spot after a rain-affected day one, with Australia's batters struggling to really get on top of Pakistan's attack. Follow live.

title.children: Head and Labuschagne trying to drive home Australia's slim advantage on day two at MCG

image.altText: A group of workers in high vis pose smiling in front of machinery from a rocket

props.synopsis: The first locally made rocket to be launched into space from Australian soil is scheduled for lift-off from a commercial facility in Queensland early next year.

title.children: An Australian-made rocket will be launched in Queensland in a historic first

image.altText: Andoo Comanche sailing.

props.synopsis: The skipper of one of the leaders in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race says it's become a "battle for survival" as competitors continue to face stormy conditions off mainland Australia's south-east coast.

title.children: 'It's a battle for survival now': Andoo Comanche, LawConnect leading the Sydney to Hobart race

image.altText: An illustration in blue and pink colours shows a woman sitting alone in a room looking out a window

props.synopsis: Long COVID is not just destroying people's health. Behind closed doors, in homes across Australia and abroad, it is irreversibly changing relationships — sometimes for the better, too often for worse.

title.children: 'This is the end of the relationship': The marriages under strain from long COVID

image.altText: A bunch of red roses on the ground outside a business office.

props.synopsis: Susan Scardigno suffered serious injuries in the alleged attack at her workplace last Wednesday, and was taken to the Royal Adelaide Hospital. Julie Seed, 38, was also allegedly stabbed and died at the scene.

title.children: Woman discharged from hospital after alleged stabbing at Adelaide real estate business

image.altText: Smoke coming from behind trees in WA's outback

props.synopsis: WA Police are investigating the death of a volunteer firefighter responding to a blaze in the Shire of Esperance in the state's south.

title.children: 'Absolute tragedy': Volunteer firefighter dies while responding to Boxing Day blaze on WA's south coast

image.altText: An Israeli soldier rides in an armoured personnel carrier in Gaza.

props.synopsis: The Israeli defence minister says Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, and Yemen among possible locations in which actions have been taken.

title.children: Israel hints that it has struck international targets in retaliation

image.altText: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny is seen on a screen via video link from a penal colony.

props.synopsis: The jailed Russian opposition politician confirmed his arrival at the IK-3 penal colony north of the Arctic Circle, which is considered Russia's toughest prison.

title.children: Alexei Navalny says he is in 'good spirits' despite transfer to Arctic prison

image.altText: red and green digits from the ASX reflected on a window with people behind it

props.synopsis: Australia's dollar is trading around US68.25 cents, having risen by 6 cents in the last two months. The ASX200 is tipped to open slightly higher.

title.children: Australia's dollar now worth US68.25 cents, ASX re-opens

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australia narrowly avoided recession this year — what these experts think will happen in 2024

image.altText: A woman holding a baby

props.synopsis: Despite a global surge in women freezing their eggs, nearly 9 out of 10 Victorians aren't returning to use their stored eggs. Advocates say more education could change what happens to them next.

title.children: More women are freezing their eggs. But what happens if they don't get used?

image.altText: A montage of black and white images of 2 women and 2 men with an artist blue graphic design on top.

props.synopsis: Australia technically avoided a recession in 2023, though living standards went backwards for most of the population. Here's what four leading economists tip could happen in 2024.

title.children: Australia narrowly avoided recession this year. Here's what these experts think will happen in 2024

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses smiles in front of the ocean with green hills in the distance

props.synopsis: Not everyone is satisfied with an office or working from home — they'd prefer to be operating from white-sand beaches and tropical rainforests. These Australians share the advantages and disadvantages of being a digital nomad.

title.children: These Australians work remotely while travelling overseas. But are they really living the dream?

image.altText: A woman in a bright outfit and hat

props.synopsis: When Meredith Campbell was diagnosed with acute depression with psychosis, she received electroconvulsive therapy. A clinical psychiatrist says there's still a widespread stigma around the treatment, despite it being deemed "safe and effective".

title.children: Six months ago, Meredith couldn't shower or drive. She says electroconvulsive therapy saved her life

image.altText: A grey navy ship on the water with land in the background.

props.synopsis: Russia says two Ukrainian fighter jets were destroyed by anti-aircraft fire during the attack, however Ukraine has denied this claim.

title.children: Russia says naval ship in Crimea was damaged in air strike by Ukrainian forces

image.altText: Side by side photos of Mary-Louise McLaws, Father Bob Maguire and Barry Humphries dressed as Dame Edna

props.synopsis: From master chefs and iconic artists to sporting legends and trailblazing politicians, Australia lost some of its most loved — and most controversial — icons this year.

title.children: Remembering the famous Australians who died this year

image.altText: A man in a shirt and jeans rides in bicycle along a bridge during the day in a Medieval-looking city.

props.synopsis: What can Australia learn from other cities reducing CBD traffic? It's about disincentives for drivers and incentives for those who choose other means of getting around.

title.children: This researcher analysed 12 ways cities are trying to cut traffic. A congestion tax worked best

image.altText: Writer Madeleine Dore smiles while looking off camera, wearing a blue turtleneck and red lipstick, in front of a pink backdrop.

props.synopsis: Unwinding doesn't come naturally to many. Even in Australia, where we have the reputation for being laid back, most people have to make a concerted effort to prioritise rest and switch off.

title.children: Nine ideas to help you unwind over the summer break

image.altText: xiangqi

props.synopsis: The Chinese Xiangqi Association was also forced to address cheating rumours which involved the rhythmic use of a sex toy.

title.children: Chinese chess world rocked by cheating rumours, bad behaviour scandal

image.altText: A young woman sitting at a table with a bag of medications.

props.synopsis: Researchers say pollen is becoming more potent, and seasons longer, as the climate changes. Hay fever sufferers, brace yourselves.

title.children: Caitlin can't imagine her allergies getting any worse. Climate change means they probably will

image.altText: A collage of colourful romance novels, most featuring cartoon illustrations of couples embracing.

props.synopsis: Readers are embracing romance novels with wild abandon and sending their favourite titles straight to number one. So we asked a bestselling romance author, publisher and bookseller why the genre is having such a moment.

title.children: The romance genre is 'blowing up' online. A bestselling author, publisher and bookseller explain why

image.altText: The poster for Spy Kids, with two children wearing sunnies doing martial arts.

props.synopsis: Incredible sets. Creative concepts that spark the imagination. Gadgets. Action. Wigs. Exciting chase scenes involving life-sized thumbs. You want it, Spy Kids has it. And I believe this film has a deeper, true meaning behind all the kid movie chaos.

title.children: 2001's Spy Kids is actually about a dad having a midlife crisis. Let me tell you why

image.altText: Sakib Kazi kneeling next to a drone.

props.synopsis: In the lead up to bushfire season, Zoos Victoria are embracing all forms of technological innovation to help ensure the survival of our most at-risk native fauna.

title.children: Drones and song meters: How Zoos Victoria is transforming conservation

image.altText: Coral bommies

props.synopsis: Once teeming with marine life, Cannindah Reef is now buried under Queensland cattle country. Could it help scientists protect the Great Barrier Reef as the climate changes?

title.children: How a long-buried, 300-million-year-old coral oasis could hold secrets to fighting climate change

image.altText: A woman in green shirt working at computer.

props.synopsis: Georgie Morse sees her ability to hyper focus on gardening tasks as a benefit of her attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder. But, ADHD has cost her in other ways — with calls for business to show understanding to people with the condition.

title.children: Georgie racked up $2,000 in parking fines, an experience she attributes to 'ADHD tax'

image.altText: Rusting cars with smashed windscreens among tropical palms.

props.synopsis: How does a pristine tropical island manage decades of rubbish? For one of Australia's most remote territories, it can be an expensive ordeal.

title.children: What does a pristine tropical island do with decades worth of dumped cars?

image.altText: White man standing next to white electric car with orange dirt

props.synopsis: A former coal, oil and gas worker, Ray Middleton believes isolation shouldn't stop people from switching to electric vehicles.

title.children: Having worked in fossil fuels for three decades, Ray concedes he's not your typical EV enthusiast

image.altText: A woman in a wetsuit speaks to divers in the open ocean.

props.synopsis: Freediving is being embraced by a growing number of Australians, and the benefits appear to be more than just physical.

title.children: 'Something magic happens': Enchanting underwater world of freediving unlocks mental health benefits
